text: Hi, this is David from MinuteEarth.

Recently, we made a video about how “life
expectancy” numbers are misleading and how

graphs can tell us way more about how long
animals are likely to live.

In that video, we looked at survival curves
of dogs, sea turtles, and modern humans.

But you curious creatures wanted to know not
just about modern humans, but also how human
survival has changed over time.

So we dug into the data to create survivorship
curves for humans throughout history.

Or, at least we tried; it’s almost impossible
to get this sort of data for all humans throughout
time.

In many places, these records got destroyed,
weren’t kept in the first place, or were
only kept for the rich and the royals.

The group that had the most complete data,
perhaps not surprisingly, was “White Males
from the post-colonial United States”.

That means our data represents only a tiny
fraction of a percent of the humans who have
ever lived, and is a pretty skewed sample.
But there are some definite takeaways.
Like, getting old isn’t new.

In the early 1800’s, the average life expectancy
of white men in the US was only 42 - yet U.S.

President John Adams was 90 when he died in
1826.

It's not like, back then, men in their 30s
were senior citizens - healthy 30-year olds

looked more or less like 30-year-olds have
always looked.

It's just that larger numbers of young people
used to die from war and disease, skewing
the average.

If we think about our mid-life survival in
relation to that of other animals, white male

Americans in the 1800s were more like wolves
- many of which die from fights and infections

- while white male Americans today are more
domestic dogs, which rarely die in the prime
of their lives.

But here’s something else worth noting - up
through the 1960s, only about a third of the

white male Americans who made it to 60 would
reach 80.

After 60, people’s bodies - and odds of
surviving - went downhill quickly, like wild

sheep, who die off quickly after reaching
middle age.

Today, though, way more than half of white
male Americans - and, indeed, humans in general
- who reach 60 make it to 80 and beyond.

We now age more like whales do; we have lots
of good years late in life.

But while whale longevity is thought to be
due to special mutations that help with DNA

repair, in modern humans, it’s mostly thanks
to the development of drugs that fight pneumonia,

which used to be the number one killer of
old folks.

But the biggest changes in human survivorship
over the last 200 years have happened at the
other end of our lives - here.

I mean, we all know we’ve reduced infant
mortality, but the actual numbers are truly
incredible.

In the early 1800s, almost a quarter of white
male Americans died in their first year of

life due to birth complications, infections,
and poor sanitation - they had about the same
odds of survival as some baby birds.

But 200 years later, thanks to breakthroughs
like widespread access to hospital care, childhood

vaccinations, and clean drinking water, very
few white male American babies died.

We’ve also seen huge gains for those outside
this admittedly non-representative group;

worldwide, human infant mortality has dropped
to less than 3%.

Of course, those gains aren’t evenly distributed
- and there is a ton of work to do to ensure
all babies have the best chance of survival.

But pretty much everywhere in the world, infant
mortality rates are continuing to improve;

by 2100, it’s expected that 99% of all kids
will make it to their first birthday.

And that curve is like … well, like no other
animal.

Developing good habits - and sticking to them
- is super hard.

But the Fabulous app uses proven methods from
behavioral science research to teach you how

to turn tiny repeatable tasks you can do every
day into all sorts of lasting useful habits.

I’ve just started using Fabulous to improve
my sleep schedule, which has gotten a little
shaky over the last year or so.

In addition to little steps to get started
- no social media before bed for 3 nights

this week - it also shows me the roadmap I’m
going to follow all the way to my goal.
